articles.headline: The Frills Are Few. The Fees Are Not.
articles.snippet: Spirit Airlines prides itself for offering the lowest fares, then charging passengers for everything else.
articles.abstract: Spirit Airlines prides itself for offering the lowest fares, then charging passengers for everything else.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a joke in the airline business that you could make money giving out free beer and charging a fee for the bathroom.

articles.headline: To Compete, G.M. Alters a Sedan
articles.snippet: The revamped Malibu, along with new pickup trucks this summer, is part of an effort by General Motors to emerge from years of retrenching after its financial collapse.
articles.abstract: The revamped Malibu, along with new pickup trucks this summer, is part of an effort by General Motors to emerge from years of retrenching after its financial collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors introduced its revamped Chevrolet Malibu sedan on Friday — just a year after it put out the latest version of the car.

articles.headline: Hunch About Bloomberg Brought Rivals Together
articles.snippet: Suspicions that Bloomberg was monitoring bank executives never amounted to much until an official at Goldman Sachs called his counterpart at JPMorgan.
articles.abstract: Suspicions that Bloomberg was monitoring bank executives never amounted to much until an official at Goldman Sachs called his counterpart at JPMorgan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are usually bitter rivals, competing for lucrative banking and trading business. But one day in April, the Wall Street titans found common ground: frustration with the Bloomberg news and financial data empire.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: One Obstacle Won’t Budge in Japan’s Fight With Deflation
articles.snippet: The Japanese government has made stemming deflation a priority, but its efforts so far have not affected everyday items, like a can of soda.
articles.abstract: The Japanese government has made stemming deflation a priority, but its efforts so far have not affected everyday items, like a can of soda.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Vending machines stocked with sodas are ubiquitous here, tucked away, it seems, in every nook and cranny of the country. They are found along Omotesando, the tree-lined shopping avenue known as the Champs-Élysées of Tokyo, and their glow lights up the back streets of hot spring towns like Hakone. They are even atop Mount Fuji, Japan’s 12,000-foot, snow-capped mountain.

articles.headline: Surpluses Help, but Fiscal Woes for States Go On
articles.snippet: The surpluses that many states are expecting this year are not as robust as they appear because of costs put off during the recession, like funding for Medicaid and pension systems.
articles.abstract: The surpluses that many states are expecting this year are not as robust as they appear because of costs put off during the recession, like funding for Medicaid and pension systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: While the fiscal picture is brightening around the country, with many states expecting surpluses this year after years of deficits and wrenching budget crises, mounting Medicaid costs and underfunded retirement promises are continuing to cloud their long-term outlook.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Quantity Over Quality in Bank Profits
articles.snippet: Stock prices and earnings have risen sharply for banks. But there is less to the headline number than some investors may think.
articles.abstract: Stock prices and earnings have risen sharply for banks. But there is less to the headline number than some investors may think.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANK stocks are back, and with a vengeance. Last week, the KBW Bank Index of 24 leading national and regional bank stocks climbed to its highest closing price since 2008. The index is up 20 percent so far in 2013 and 40 percent if you measure from 12 months ago.

articles.headline: U.S. and China Agree to Hold Regular Talks on Hacking
articles.snippet: The United States hopes the dialogue can help set norms and end what it says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets by Chinese hackers.
articles.abstract: The United States hopes the dialogue can help set norms and end what it says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets by Chinese hackers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and China have agreed to hold regular, high-level talks on how to set standards of behavior for cybersecurity and commercial espionage, the first diplomatic effort to defuse the tensions over what the United States says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mark Landler

articles.headline: This Man Is Not a Cyborg. Yet.
articles.snippet: The Russian multimillionaire Dmitry Itskov wants us all to live forever, our minds inside avatars. And he is spending a bundle to try to make his colossal dream happen.
articles.abstract: The Russian multimillionaire Dmitry Itskov wants us all to live forever, our minds inside avatars. And he is spending a bundle to try to make his colossal dream happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: GET right up close to Dmitry Itskov and sniff all you like — you will not pick up even the faintest hint of crazy. He is soft-spoken and a bit shy, but expansive once he gets talking, and endearingly mild-mannered. He never seems ruffled, no matter what question you ask. Even if you ask the obvious one, which he has encountered more than a few times since 2011, when he started “this project,” as he sometimes calls it.

articles.headline: Pugnacious Builder of the Business Lobby
articles.snippet: In 16 years, Thomas Donohue has transformed the U.S. Chamber of Commerce into a lobbying powerhouse — and into a much more political animal.
articles.abstract: In 16 years, Thomas Donohue has transformed the U.S. Chamber of Commerce into a lobbying powerhouse — and into a much more political animal.
articles.lead_paragraph: THOMAS J. DONOHUE is not one for sweet talk. No sooner had he been named president of the United States Chamber of Commerce in 1997 than he promised to “make life miserable” for Bill Archer, a powerful member of Congress. In the next breath, he suggested that John Sweeney, the union leader, needed to be punched in the mouth.

articles.headline: As Syrians Fight, Sectarian Strife Infects Mideast
articles.snippet: The war is setting off a contagious sectarian conflict in Iraq and Lebanon, rekindling long-simmering tensions.
articles.abstract: The war is setting off a contagious sectarian conflict in Iraq and Lebanon, rekindling long-simmering tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Renewed sectarian killing has brought the highest death toll in Iraq in five years. Young Iraqi scholars at a Shiite Muslim seminary volunteer to fight Sunnis in Syria. Far to the west, in Lebanon, clashes have worsened between opposing sects in the northern city of Tripoli.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Anne Barnard and Duraid Adnan

articles.headline: Seeking a Fresh Start, Holder Finds a Fresh Set of Troubles
articles.snippet: Some in the West Wing privately wish Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. would step down, but resistance may stiffen for fear of emboldening opponents.
articles.abstract: Some in the West Wing privately wish Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. would step down, but resistance may stiffen for fear of emboldening opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the end of last year, with the election decided and the Obama administration in office for four more years, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. considered stepping down. He decided against it, in part because before he left he wanted to move beyond the disputes that had characterized his tenure, accomplish some of the goals he had set for the job and leave on his own terms.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Charlie Savage and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Trial on E-Book Price-Fixing Puts Apple in Spotlight
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s lawsuit that accuses Apple of colluding with publishers to raise e-book prices will begin in United States District Court.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s lawsuit that accuses Apple of colluding with publishers to raise e-book prices will begin in United States District Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government lawyers are set to face off against Apple this week in a Manhattan courtroom, trying to prove that the company conspired with publishers to raise prices in the e-book market.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Chasing the Storm, but Hoping Not to Catch It
articles.snippet: Interest in storm chasing has surged, with amateurs now jockeying with seasoned professionals. The risks of the hobby were apparent Sunday when relatives confirmed the death of a veteran chaser.
articles.abstract: Interest in storm chasing has surged, with amateurs now jockeying with seasoned professionals. The risks of the hobby were apparent Sunday when relatives confirmed the death of a veteran chaser.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tim Samaras began chasing tornadoes more than two decades ago, he was one of a small, mostly anonymous group of scientists and thrill seekers armed with paper maps, weather radios and a sense of wonder.

articles.headline: F.D.A. to Reconsider Restrictions on Diabetes Drug
articles.snippet: In a highly unusual move, the agency has decided to reopen the case on Avandia and will ask a committee whether it should reconsider the restrictions on the drug.
articles.abstract: In a highly unusual move, the agency has decided to reopen the case on Avandia and will ask a committee whether it should reconsider the restrictions on the drug.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, in one of the more notable drug-safety scandals in recent history, the diabetes drug Avandia was all but banned from use in the United States after researchers found that thousands of people had heart problems after taking it. Today, it is a drug of last resort for people with diabetes who are so sick that a heart attack is worth the risk.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Google’s Washington Insider
articles.snippet: Susan Molinari, a brassy, well-connected New York Republican who served seven years in the House, now works to broaden Google’s support beyond Silicon Valley Democrats.
articles.abstract: Susan Molinari, a brassy, well-connected New York Republican who served seven years in the House, now works to broaden Google’s support beyond Silicon Valley Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Susan Molinari had wrapped up her second week as Google’s chief Washington lobbyist when she got a call at home late on a Friday that blindsided her: the Federal Communications Commission was fining Google $25,000 for having “deliberately impeded and delayed” an investigation into its Street View mapping project.

articles.headline: Devoted to Politics, MSNBC Slips on Breaking News
articles.snippet: The network experienced a ratings decline in the last two months, as viewers turned away from Washington and toward disaster coverage.
articles.abstract: The network experienced a ratings decline in the last two months, as viewers turned away from Washington and toward disaster coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: At MSNBC they view it as rooting against death and destruction: the last thing the channel wants is more months like the last two, filled with terror bombings, tornadoes and plant accidents.

articles.headline: Protests in Turkey Reveal a Larger Fight Over Identity
articles.snippet: For many Turks, the development of urban spaces is not so much progress as a reflection of growing autocratic ambitions by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
articles.abstract: For many Turks, the development of urban spaces is not so much progress as a reflection of growing autocratic ambitions by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Across this vast city, a capital for three former empires, cranes dangle over construction sites, tin walls barricade old slums, and skyscrapers outclimb the mosque minarets that have dominated the skyline for centuries — all a vanguard for more audacious projects already in the works.

articles.headline: Women in the Senate Confront the Military on Sex Assaults
articles.snippet: The growing presence of women senators is most pronounced on the Armed Services Committee, where they have forced the long-simmering issue of sexual assault in the military to the forefront.
articles.abstract: The growing presence of women senators is most pronounced on the Armed Services Committee, where they have forced the long-simmering issue of sexual assault in the military to the forefront.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Claire McCaskill wandered down the dais at the Senate Armed Services Committee’s first hearing of the year and noticed a startling tableau: women to the left, women to the right.

articles.headline: Chinese Bid for U.S. Pork Had Links to Wall Street
articles.snippet: The bid for Smithfield Foods, America’s biggest pork producer, points to a type of cooperation between Wall Street and Asia’s elites that may be on the rise.
articles.abstract: The bid for Smithfield Foods, America’s biggest pork producer, points to a type of cooperation between Wall Street and Asia’s elites that may be on the rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a Chinese company bid $4.7 billion last week to take over Smithfield Foods, America’s biggest pork producer, the deal was announced by the company’s Chinese executives.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund, Under Fire, Braces for Withdrawals
articles.snippet: Steven A. Cohen’s SAC Capital Advisors, long under investigation, faces what could be billions of dollars in withdrawals by a Monday deadline. Prosecutors face a deadline of their own.
articles.abstract: Steven A. Cohen’s SAC Capital Advisors, long under investigation, faces what could be billions of dollars in withdrawals by a Monday deadline. Prosecutors face a deadline of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: The embattled hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is bracing for investors to pull out as much as several billion dollars by a Monday deadline. Withdrawals have stepped up as a separate deadline looms for law enforcement officials investigating the firm.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Pressure Grows to Create Drugs for ‘Superbugs’
articles.snippet: Experts are considering ways to speed the approval of new medicines to combat antibiotic-resistant infections, but high costs and safety concerns have complicated their efforts.
articles.abstract: Experts are considering ways to speed the approval of new medicines to combat antibiotic-resistant infections, but high costs and safety concerns have complicated their efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government officials, drug companies and medical experts, faced with outbreaks of antibiotic-resistant “superbugs,” are pushing to speed up the approval of new antibiotics, a move that is raising safety concerns among some critics.

articles.headline: China Is Reaping Biggest Benefits of Iraq Oil Boom
articles.snippet: Since the toppling of Saddam Hussein, Chinese state-owned companies have poured workers and billions of dollars into Iraq to secure a steady supply of energy for China.
articles.abstract: Since the toppling of Saddam Hussein, Chinese state-owned companies have poured workers and billions of dollars into Iraq to secure a steady supply of energy for China.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Since the American-led invasion of 2003, Iraq has become one of the world’s top oil producers, and China is now its biggest customer.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Justices Allow DNA Collection After an Arrest
articles.snippet: In a 5-to-4 ruling, the Supreme Court said DNA samples were similar to the photographs and fingerprints taken while booking criminal suspects.
articles.abstract: In a 5-to-4 ruling, the Supreme Court said DNA samples were similar to the photographs and fingerprints taken while booking criminal suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The police may take DNA samples from people arrested in connection with serious crimes, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.
